main event: A 'flying disc' was observed at Moses Lake Air Force Base, Washington at approximately 0545 hours local time on 23 May 1949 by multiple pilots. The object appeared to be traveling at a very high rate of speed and remained in view for 1 to 1 1/2 minutes on a straight and level course before disappearing from sight.
interesting points: The object had no definite shape discernible and appeared very small from the point of observation.
It was estimated to be traveling at a very high rate of speed, and its heading was between 015 - 020 degrees.
The report was made by credible witnesses, including Lt Col Walter C. Searle, Lt Col Wallace Jordan, and 1st Lt Gerald J Bliss, all pilots.
The object was estimated to be 8-10 miles from the base, and it was observed at an estimated altitude of 10,000 - 15,000 ft.
No sound or exhaust trail was reported, and the object's maneuverability was noted to be none.
The report was addressed to the Commanding General of Air Material Command at Wright-Patterson AF Base, Dayton, Ohio.
location: Moses Lake Air Force Base, Washington
